a t2 instance gets cpu credits and each credit provides the performance of one
CPU core and this is actually important that it offers a full CPU core not a not a hyper thread which is what most ec2
instances offer offers a full CPU core for one minute so every credit that you see will be one minute worth of using a
CPU 100% so an instance earns CPU credits at a constant rate and so every
different size I've earned a different number of credits per minute and so as
long as that instance is turned on its gonna be earning credits and then it can consume credits whenever it wants to burst and use the CPU so whenever you
try and use you know use some CPU that will use up some of your credits and then credits expire every 24 hours
so the credits you earn 24 hours ago we expire 24 hours later and this is what really makes sure that that sliding
window is going to average over the last 24 hours of utilization and to really the the net result of all of this is
kind of what I was talking about in the previous examples which is that at the high level you really just have to think
about is my average utilization over a trailing 24 hour window higher or lower than the amount of burst capacity I get
with a t2 instance and so for sort of the gory details of that this is what we
